awd_titl_txt: Excellence in Research: An HBCU Partnership to Leverage Resources and Increase Scientific Productivity in Observational Time Domain Astrophysics
awd_abstract_narration:
South Carolina State University (SCSU) and the University of the University of the Virgin Islands (UVI) will enhance their research capabilities in astrophysics by combining their astrophysical resources to form a Time Domain Astrophysical Collaboration (TDAC) which will significantly increase their scientific productivity and move them into the growing field of time domain astrophysics.  The TDAC schools manage or partner in the management of two small aperture telescopes located in the United States Virgin Islands and at Kitt Peak National Observatory. This project will allow both institutions to build research capacity through the addition of personnel, faculty and student support, and improvements to their physical infrastructure.

The project will add a Resident Observer to the UVI facility and SCSU will hire its first ever Postdoctoral Researcher in astronomy. These enhancements will allow them to participate in coordinated research with the greater astronomical community in multimessenger  observations of the electromagnetic counterparts  of gravitational waves, monitoring  Active Galactic Nuclei  and contributing to Living with a Red Dwarf project on K and M dwarf stars through use their telescope facilities in Arizona (SCSU)and in the Virgin Islands (UVI).  This grant will result in the enhanced research capabilities of the faculty  and recruitment and retention of STEM undergraduate majors at SCSU and UVI through internships, campus research talks, and the incorporation of project results into the curriculum of both institutions, including physics and computer science. It will result in motivating minority students at both institutions to continue on to graduate school or enter the workforce in STEM fields.   

This project is jointly funded by the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), and HBCU's Excellence in Research (EIR) Program and managed by MPS/AST.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Excellence in Research: An HBCU Partnership to Leverage Resources and Increase Scientific Productivity in Observational Time Domain Astrophysics 

The NSF solicitation for the HBCU Excellence in Research (EiR) program stated it will  support projects that enable STEM and STEM education faculty to further develop research capacity at HBCUs and to conduct research. This EiR award was highly successful at not one, but two HBCUs.  South Carolina State University (SCSU) and the University of the Virgin Islands (UVI), partnered to form a Time Domain Astrophysical Collaboration which increased scientific productivity at both schools and prepared them to participate in future research in time-domain and multi-messenger astrophysics. During the period of the project, 2019-2023, the two schools engaged in a variety of activities including publishing of research by faculty and a postdoc, undergraduate research experiences, hosting of numerous educational and public outreach (EPO) programs and perhaps the most lasting impact of this award was the upgrade of their two observatories to better facilitate current and future research. We note that during the early years of the award the COVID pandemic struck, and this impacted the initial amount of science and EPO that was carried out, but the schools rebounded, and the final few years were highly productive.

            UVI astronomers have used the Virgin Islands Robotic Telescope (VIRT) in the past to observe the optical follow-on to Gamma Ray Burst (GRB) transients identified by the NASA Swift satellite.  The EiR award allowed then to hire an experienced Observatory Specialist who improved the observing techniques, trained undergraduates and improved image processing procedures. The equipment at the Etelman Observatory at UVI was upgraded and improved the overall operation of the facility. This award enabled the faculty and staff to respond more quickly to unexpected GRBs and to increase their publication of GRB afterglow observations.

            SCSU astronomers used funding from EiR to continue their studies and publish their results on semi-regular stars, which are red or yellow giants or supergiants that pulsate with periods that are not quite regular and do not repeat as nicely as other variables. Additionally, SCSU was able to hire a postdoctoral research associate who contributed to the program at the school for two years.  In addition to assisting with the faculty research, the postdoc conducted her own work and was able to publish several articles related to infrared radiation in active galactic nuclei (AGNs) of galaxies.  SCSU is a partner in the Robotically Controlled Telescope (RCT) Consortium.  The RCT is a 1.3-meter telescope located at Kitt Peak National Observatory. The 20-year-old camera on the RCT failed and was no longer operational at the time the EiR award began.  With funds from the EiR along with a NSF supplement award, a new, state of the art camera was purchased and installed on the RCT.  The imagery is now better than it has been in many years and the telescope is producing useful science.

            Both UVI and SCSU carried out numerous EPO activities over the lifetime of EiR. These included public observing sessions with VIRT, talks to the campus community and public by faculty and visiting scientists as well as K-12 visits (in person and virtual) that reached hundreds of students over the period of the award. Since both institutions are HBCUs and their local communities reflect the demographics of the schools, the EiR largely impacted groups that historically been underrepresented in astronomy and astrophysics.

            This EiR award allowed UVI and SCSU to work together for the first time and the  collaborative spirit from the project has developed into a lasting partnership.  The two schools combined again to write a new, four-year proposal that was awarded under the NSF Partnership in Astronomy and Astrophysics Research and Education program.  They added Clemson University to their partnership and will spend the next four years in time domain, multi-messenger astrophysics studying transients such GRBs, AGNs and new variable stars identified by the Rubin Observatory (formally known as the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope or LSST) as the facility begins its first years of operation.
